references:
Table 2 shows the performance of both centralized and federated methods across the four datasets.
The results highlight that FedMR significantly boosts the performance of the used FedRec methods, particularly in the KU dataset, where HR@50 for FedAvg, FCF, PFedRec, and FedRAP exhibits notable improvements.
This indicates that FedMR effectively enhances traditional ID-based FedRec methods by integrating multimodal item information. The performance improvements in other datasets further demonstrate FedMR’s ability to alleviate data sparsity by better leveraging users’ interaction histories alongside multimodal data for more personalized recommendations, while protecting user privacy.
Compared to centralized MMRec methods, FedRec approaches using FedMR achieve similar or even superior performance while maintaining privacy, e.g., in the KU dataset, FedAvg with FedMR surpasses all centralized methods in terms of HR@50.
Federated methods with FedMR also perform strongly across other datasets, reinforcing FedMR’s capability to improve recommendation quality without sacrificing user privacy.

Despite the increase in the number of learnable parameters, Table 2 demonstrates that FedMR significantly improves the recommendation performance of FedRec on the KU dataset.
By combining multimodal features with ID embeddings, FedMR better leverages users’ interaction histories to capture the fine-grained personality of users.
Additionally, the mixing feature fusion module in FedMR adjusts the weights of multimodal features based on users’ interaction history, greatly enhancing both the accuracy and personalization of recommendations.
Moreover, compared to traditional FedRec methods, which rely solely on the ID embeddings, FedMR enables personalized modeling by integrating multimodal information, thereby further improving recommendation quality. While the model’s complexity increases, this trade-off results in significant performance gains.

references: Table 3 presents a performance comparison of the five used ID-based FedRec methods with the inclusion of multimodal information. It evaluates these methods under the full model (FedMR) and with the removal of visual modality (w/o V), textual modality (w/o C), and ID features (w/o D), focusing on HR@50 and NDCG@50 metrics.

NDCG@50 0.1305 0.1236 5.29% ↓↓\downarrow↓
references:
Table 4 presents the experimental results of the used FedRec methods combined with FedMR, comparing the performance with and without adding Gaussian noise (mean=0, variance=0.1) to the gradients of the global components uploaded to the server, to protect user privacy.
The experiments are conducted on the KU dataset during feature fusion.
The results indicate that all methods experienced some performance degradation after adding noise, particularly on the NDCG metric, which is more sensitive to ranking accuracy. This is because noise disturbs the gradient precision, which affects the model’s ability to update effectively.

references:
Table 5 illustrates the change in the number of learnable parameters on a single client in the KU dataset when FedMR is integrated into FedRec or not, compared to centralized recommendation systems.
As shown in the table, the introduction of FedMR significantly increases the parameter size.
This is because FedMR incorporates multimodal information (e.g., visual and textual features) alongside ID embeddings, increasing the model’s complexity and consequently requiring more parameters to learn.
